posts.cooked: Hello, we are having an issue where our Pathplanner paths occasionally go slow and don’t reach the setpoint. The issue appears to be random as our autos only work 50% of the time even when we don’t change anything in the code or PathPlanner Here is a match where it doesn’t work (look for 5675): https://youtu.be/JsTglLVHq_Y?t=4 and here is one of it working: https://youtu.be/qbDJyDn2NhQ?t=3 . Those autos are the exact same. To fix the issue, we deploy the code, and the issue is gone (sometimes), but then it comes back sometimes seemingly at random. We have tried increasing the P on angle and drive but the issue is still there. We have also tried using PuTTY to reset PathPlanner (thanks to team 3572 Wavelength) with no luck either. We’re thinking it could be an issue with our max velocity or acceleration, but that doesn’t explain why the path works and sometimes it doesn’t. Our next guess is that there is a CAN overload, but when the auto doesn’t work, teleop is just fine. Here is our code: Github . Thanks for helping!

posts.name: Blake
posts.cooked: We have been experiencing this a few times this weekend with no known fix yet. We ran the same paths in our last regional without this issue. We thought maybe the acceleration was too low and turned it up slightly and our last 3 matches ran well. Unsure if the issue is gone but we’ll report back if we figure anything else out.

posts.name: Abu
posts.cooked:
jacob_mazelin:

paths occasionally go slow and don’t reach the setpoint

Sounds like a PID issue.

link_counts.title: PathPlanner Need Help to use with YAGSL

posts.cooked: It could be. The autos worked at our last competition. The only thing we changed with autos from our last competition was increasing the P for both angle and velocity, lowering the max acceleration, and increasing the max velocity. I wouldn’t think increasing the P would make it not reach the set point, but we can try going back to the same values as our last competition.

posts.name: Hunter Rothman
posts.cooked: Are your robot wheels slipping in auto? If they are that will build an odometry error and autos won’t run right. Also, I see your limelight code is all commented out. Make sure if you do use that for pose estimation you only pull from blue relative. Pathplanner is blue relative so your pose estimation needs to be blue relative.

posts.name: Abu
posts.cooked: Sorry, I didn’t watch the videos previously. I take it back, it doesn’t seem like a PID issue. Take a look at the log files and update us on any inconsistencies.

So we ran three autos on blue and they worked great, but the one auto we ran on red had the issue. I’ve seen it happen on blue before so I don’t think that’s a coincidence. We disconnected CAN from three motors, so it’s not a CAN overload, and we set the max acceleration and max velocity back to what it was at our last competition when the autos worked just fine. I don’t believe it’s a battery problem either because the autos can work on a bad battery. It could be an issue where one or two swerves are getting incorrect odometry, but we use Pathplanner for that, not limelight, so I’m not sure how it could only be two swerves and not all four. Any other thoughts?
Does your issue appear to be random as well? Also, what motors are you using? We’re using NEO vortexes for drive and NEO 1.1s for angle. We’re thinking it could be a motor issue.

posts.name: Blake
posts.cooked:
We have Neo 1.1 on both drive and turn. It definitely seemed random yesterday. We didn’t have any issues today after we turned up the acceleration a touch yesterday. Our theory is that maybe we didn’t have enough acceleration to overcome whatever drag/friction was happening.

We had lowered our acceleration between regionals to try and reduce slip. Seemed to be the only change and the issue went away after we increased it.

posts.name: Abu
posts.cooked: Can you pull up the log files and tell us what you see?

We turned up our acceleration to what it was at our last competition and it worked three times in a row. It didn’t work the fourth time. We increased it from 2.7 to 3, but we might need to go higher to overcome the drag. Just out of curiosity, what are your acceleration and velocity values for both drive and angle?
I would if I could, but the drive computer is in the shop, so I won’t be able to access it for some time. I’ll let you know as soon as I can.

posts.name: Blake
posts.cooked: We’re using MK4, L3, and our settings are Velocity 4.50 and Acceleration 2.00. Looks like you are running higher accel, so maybe not the same issue we were seeing

posts.name: AfterTen
posts.cooked:
I’ve been thinking about your issue since MCS ended. So when you can get to the driver station and the log files I’d be interested to see if you are getting any brownouts in the log file during the failed auto tries.

I understand that one wouldn’t think you should get a brownout on a fresh battery at the start of a match. But if you are starting almost every motor on the robot, as we are apt to do during an auto, it could happen.

If you are getting a brownout this would explain the behavior. When the Rio sees a brownouts it sends an explicit “disable” to every CAN based motor. So you would get a stutter then when the brownout resolves the motors start again but because this is an auto your odometery would show you way out of place and pathplanner is going to max the motors again to try and get the robot to catch up. So another brownout occurs and you get into a vicious loop.

posts.name: B.Hummel
posts.cooked: Thanks for thinking more about this.  We will certainly look at the logs when we get back into the shop (currently taking a little break).  However, my guess is that this is not the issue.  We actually were able to see the stuttering while running the auto routine on the cart.  This occurred after you looked at it.  We observed that the 2 rear swerve drive motors were stuttering badly during auto but the front two drive motors and all the azimuth motors seemed to be fine as far as we could tell.  Since this happened while sitting on the cart, the wheels were not experiencing any drag and should have been pulling less current than normal.

posts.name: AfterTen
posts.cooked: No problem. You don’t happen to have your code out on github to look at?
Yes, our code is here . Feel free to take a look!

I took a few pictures of the log. The first two are when the autos worked, and the second two are when the issue appeared. When the issue occurs, Pathplanner knows that it’s not following the path, so the odometry is correct. Another thing we tried was lowering the CAN Bus Utilization by taking our blowers off of the CAN , and we thought that was the problem when it worked 3 matches in a row, but then the issue came back in our last match. Do you still think it’s a battery problem?
